codes.title: Conductor Ampacity — Allowable Ampacities
codes.simplifiedExplanation: This table specifies the maximum current a wire can safely carry based on its gauge (size) and insulation type. For copper conductors at 60C: 14 AWG = 15A, 12 AWG = 20A, 10 AWG = 30A, 8 AWG = 40A, 6 AWG = 55A. Using undersized wire creates a fire hazard because the wire will overheat under load.
codes.visualHintText: Check wire thickness vs breaker rating: 14 AWG (thinnest) = 15A max, 12 AWG = 20A max, 10 AWG = 30A max. Thicker wire = more ampacity.

codes.title: Circuit Directory or Circuit Identification
codes.simplifiedExplanation: Every circuit breaker panel must have a legible directory that identifies each circuit by location and purpose. The directory must be mounted on the panel door or immediately adjacent. Each circuit must be clearly labeled (e.g., 'Kitchen Outlets', 'Master Bedroom', 'HVAC'). Blank or illegible directories are code violations.
codes.visualHintText: Look at the panel door — is there a complete, legible label for every breaker? Each breaker number must have a description.

codes.title: Unused Openings
codes.simplifiedExplanation: All unused openings (knockout holes) in panel enclosures must be effectively closed to afford protection substantially equivalent to the wall of the enclosure. This means installing listed knockout filler plates. Open holes expose live components to contact by fingers, tools, pests, and debris — creating shock and fire hazards.
codes.visualHintText: Check all sides of the panel enclosure — are there any open holes that should be covered with a knockout filler plate?

codes.title: Grounded and Ungrounded Conductor Terminations
codes.simplifiedExplanation: Each breaker terminal is designed for one conductor only, unless the breaker is specifically listed and labeled for multiple conductors. 'Double-tapping' — connecting two wires to one breaker terminal — causes loose connections, arcing, and potential fire. The fix is to install a tandem breaker or add a separate breaker for the second circuit.
codes.visualHintText: Examine each breaker terminal closely — are two wires crammed into any single terminal? That is double-tapping and a serious violation.

codes.title: Maximum Number of Overcurrent Devices
codes.simplifiedExplanation: A panelboard must not contain more overcurrent devices (circuit breakers or fuses) than the number for which the panelboard was designed, rated, and listed. The maximum number of spaces is marked on the panel data plate. Exceeding this number by using tandem breakers in non-tandem-rated slots is a violation.
codes.visualHintText: Count all breakers including tandems — the total must not exceed the number on the panel's rating label (e.g., '24 spaces / 42 circuits').

codes.title: Grounding Electrode System
codes.simplifiedExplanation: A grounding electrode system must include all grounding electrodes that are present at a building: metal underground water pipe, metal frame of the building, concrete-encased electrode (Ufer ground), ground ring, rod and pipe electrodes, and plate electrodes. All electrodes present must be bonded together. The grounding electrode conductor connects this system to the service equipment (panel). Proper grounding protects against electric shock, lightning, and equipment damage.
codes.visualHintText: Trace the ground wire from the ground bar — does it connect properly to a grounding electrode? Check for continuity of the grounding path.

codes.title: Means of Identifying Grounded Conductors
codes.section: Article 200 — Use and Identification of Grounded Conductors
codes.simplifiedExplanation: The grounded (neutral) conductor must be identified by a continuous white or gray outer finish, or by three continuous white or gray stripes along the conductor's length. This ensures the neutral can always be distinguished from hot conductors.
codes.visualHintText: The neutral wire should be white or gray. Connect it to the neutral (silver-colored) bus bar, not the hot bus.

codes.title: Outlet Devices — Receptacle Rating
codes.simplifiedExplanation: Receptacle outlets must have an amperage rating appropriate for the branch circuit. On a single-receptacle circuit, the receptacle must match the circuit rating exactly. On a multi-receptacle circuit: 15A circuit allows only 15A receptacles; 20A circuit allows both 15A and 20A receptacles; 30A+ circuits require exact match. A 20A receptacle has a distinctive T-shaped neutral slot to accept 20A plugs.
codes.visualHintText: Check the receptacle face plate — what amperage is stamped on it? On a 15A circuit only 15A outlets are allowed. On a 20A circuit you can use 15A or 20A outlets.

codes.title: Length of Free Conductors at Outlets, Junctions, and Switch Points
codes.section: Article 300 — General Requirements for Wiring Methods and Materials
codes.simplifiedExplanation: At each outlet, junction, and switch point, at least 150mm (6 inches) of free conductor must be left for splicing or connecting to devices. At least 75mm (3 inches) must extend outside the box opening. Short wires make connections difficult and unreliable.
codes.visualHintText: Check wire length in the box — at least 6 inches of free wire should extend for making connections. Measure from where the wire enters the box.

codes.title: Electrical Connections — Termination Provisions
codes.simplifiedExplanation: Connections must be made with devices identified for the wire type and size. Terminals for more than one conductor must be so identified. Torque values specified by the manufacturer must be followed. Loose connections cause arcing, overheating, and fire.
codes.visualHintText: Check all screw terminals — are they properly tightened? Use the correct torque. Each terminal should have only one wire unless rated for multiple.

codes.title: Switch Connections
codes.simplifiedExplanation: Three-way and four-way switches must be wired so that switching occurs only in the ungrounded (hot) conductor. The common terminal of a 3-way switch connects to either the line hot or the load, while the traveler terminals connect to the traveler wires between switches.
codes.visualHintText: Identify the common terminal (darker screw) on each 3-way switch. Line hot goes to switch 1 common, load goes to switch 2 common. Travelers connect the brass-colored terminals.

codes.title: Use of White or Gray Conductors
codes.section: Article 200 — Use and Identification of Grounded Conductors
codes.simplifiedExplanation: White or gray conductors shall only be used as grounded (neutral) conductors. Exception: in a switch loop using cable without a neutral, a white wire may be used as an ungrounded conductor if it is permanently re-identified (marked with tape or paint) at each visible and accessible location.
codes.visualHintText: In a switch loop using 2-wire cable, the white wire may be used as a hot conductor but must be marked with black or red tape at both ends to show it is NOT a neutral.

codes.title: Ground-Fault Circuit-Interrupter Protection for Personnel
codes.simplifiedExplanation: GFCI protection is required for all 125V, 15A and 20A receptacles in: bathrooms, garages, outdoors, crawl spaces, unfinished basements, kitchens (serving countertops), laundry areas, and within 6 feet of sinks. GFCI outlets detect current imbalances as small as 5mA and trip to prevent electrocution.
codes.visualHintText: GFCI outlets have TEST and RESET buttons. Press TEST to trip the GFCI — power should cut off. Press RESET to restore power. If it won't trip or reset, the GFCI is faulty and must be replaced.

codes.title: Receptacle Mounting and Tamper Resistance
codes.section: Article 406 — Receptacles, Cord Connectors, and Attachment Plugs
codes.simplifiedExplanation: Receptacles must be mounted securely in their boxes. In dwelling units, all 125V 15A and 20A receptacles must be tamper-resistant (TR) type. Tamper-resistant receptacles have internal shutters that prevent insertion of foreign objects into the slots.
codes.visualHintText: Check that receptacles are firmly mounted and not loose. In residential locations, look for 'TR' marking on the outlet face indicating tamper resistance.

codes.title: Bends — Number of Bends (EMT)
codes.simplifiedExplanation: Between pull points (boxes, conduit bodies, fittings), there shall not be more than the equivalent of four quarter bends (360 degrees total) in a single conduit run. Excessive bends make it extremely difficult or impossible to pull wires through the conduit and can damage conductor insulation.
codes.visualHintText: Count all the bends in your conduit run. A 90-degree bend = one quarter bend. Total all bends — they must not exceed 360 degrees between junction boxes.

codes.title: Reaming and Deburring (EMT)
codes.simplifiedExplanation: All cut ends of EMT conduit must be reamed or otherwise finished to remove rough edges. Sharp edges on un-reamed conduit will damage wire insulation during pulling, leading to shorts, ground faults, or fire. Always ream both inside and outside edges after cutting.
codes.visualHintText: After cutting conduit, use a reaming tool to smooth the inside edges. Run your finger around the cut end — if you feel any sharp burrs, it needs more reaming.

codes.title: Number of Conductors in Outlet, Device, and Junction Boxes
codes.section: Article 314 — Outlet, Device, Pull, and Junction Boxes
codes.simplifiedExplanation: Boxes must be large enough to accommodate the number of conductors, devices, and fittings they contain. Each conductor counts as a volume allowance based on its gauge (14 AWG = 2.0 cubic inches, 12 AWG = 2.25 cubic inches). Overfilling a box creates a fire hazard from damaged insulation and poor heat dissipation.
codes.visualHintText: Count all conductors entering the box and calculate total volume. Compare to the box volume stamped on the box. Include allowances for devices, clamps, and grounds.
